title: Lifesteal is still a plauge of game balance
body:
Pretty much the title. It causes massive mid-fight bulk and provides more healing than all for 1 soraka. 
The only counters don't even half it, and are more a side effect of creating a counter to healing supports. 

It's the only stat in the game which inherently converts one side of the offense/defense stat divide into the opposite, after spell vamp was removed. Though, even spell vamp was mostly problematic on champions which had no costs associated with their magic damage, where as lifesteal is triggered by something which costs the champion nothing.

Not only that.

Lifesteal also ties the ADC's survivability to their damage output. That both emphasizes the need for ADCs to build offensively and also makes them susceptible to burst damage and interruption, while guaranteeing that they need to be focused to be taken out entirely.
If Lifesteal did not exist, ADCs could be taken out by incidential, non-focused AoE damage quite rapidly. That would mean that their uptime in fights gets drastically lowered - and they'd need to be balanced around that.
And balancing them in that way would either make them horribly oppressive in the little time they stay up (increasing their damage output) or make them more survivable through health and resistances, negating their intended weakness of burst damage and interruption.

Static health may make mages more durable, but they still come nowhere close to tanks or fighters in terms of survivability. By contrast, if the marksman doesn't get bursted down, their life steal can allow them to heal from any lesser source of damage at no cost or down time. In addition to scaling into the highest damage in the game, marksmen thus end up also becoming de facto drain tanks, to a greater capacity than champions designed for that same function, like Swain, Vladimir or Warwick.

The thing is, this isn't good for marksmen either, because it's what's forcing mages and assassins to have burst that's either too high or too low on counterplay. Since the purpose of those classes is to take out the enemy back line, which includes the marksman, and that marksman can a) heal for hundreds of health every second, and b) deal hundreds of guaranteed damage a second to any target in range, if they can't burn through the ADC's ~3000 effective health within a couple of seconds, they will die and their work will be erased in the next few seconds that follow. Effectively, you end up needing to give these burst champions about 3000-4000 damage in a quick rotation that also allows them to either escape safely or operate from a safe distance, just so that they can have a chance of doing their job right. This feels fair to no one, least of all the marksman, but it's a necessary evil in an environment where their vulnerability to damage is so binary.

Taking this into account, the game would likely be in a much better state without life steal: marksmen are supposed to be naturally weak to burst and strong against DPS, and while the lack of life steal would give burst champions more leeway against them without needing ultra-reliable or overly strong damage, it would also not significantly hamper marksmen against other DPS champions, i.e. fighters and other marksmen: marksman vs. marksman fights would be a little less item-dependent, and fighters would still have trouble due to how they are naturally vulnerable to kiting. In fact, this would also be a good opportunity to take the burst out of of several Divers, such as Hecarim or Vi, as they wouldn't need it to hold up against the back line. Similarly, assassins and mages could afford to have more counterplay and unreliability injected into their own kits, as there are still quite a few outliers, e.g. Malzahar, Rengar, Syndra, etc. that aren't fun to play against, and/or have been bent out of shape after repeated balancing.

Marksmen still are weak to burst, even with their life still. And if you took out like still, a lot of marksmen would be pretty much completely defenseless against burst damage which would be really bad and make some marksmen no longer fun to play. 

If a marksman ever gets to the point in a game where they aren't weak to burst, that's because you're team screwed up and fed them a ton while not getting any of their burst champions fed enough.

I think you missed the point. Marksmen are weak to burst _now_ because the burst of assassins and mages is balanced with their life steal in mind, and is supposed to be high enough to surpass it. However, the high, near-instant amount of burst required to achieve this is generally so high and so low on counterplay that it does not feel good to suffer it. Additionally, as you pointed out, it makes burst champions even more binary, because if they fall behind relative to the marksman they just can't do their job.

An analogy for this is that burst is like pressing down on the accelerator, and life steal is pressing down on the brakes: because they both go up against each other, they somewhat cancel each other out, but slamming down on both at the same time, as is the case now, is still detrimental overall.

Toning down both life steal _and_ burst at the same time, or taking out life steal and adjusting burst accordingly, would leave the state of damage in the game in a place where marksmen could be just as weak to burst without being _too_ weak, and where we wouldn't need any damage source to be excessive in order to be effective. A world without life steal is a world where tanks don't need major ambient damage to make themselves noticed, where mages can't be excused for deleting enemies from a safe distance with a single ability rotation, and where assassins don't have to auto-murder squishies just to stay relevant.

Okay, I see your point. However, I know I find it kind of annoying to come into a fight, get burst down but survive and have to retreat because I have no means of healing in order to stay and help my team. I honestly think the better solution to this whole problem would be to nerf life steal, rather than remove it.

Having to retreat after taking a lot of damage is a problem almost every champion in any other class has to contend with already. If that is an issue that needs to be addressed, it would likely be better to do it through changes to the environment or the like, such as additional healing on plants or monster camps, rather than through class-exclusive resourceless self-healing.
